raw_text:
Durex maker SSL awaits firm bid
 
 UK condom maker SSL International has refused to comment on reports it may be subject to a takeover early in 2005.
 
 A Financial Times report said business intelligence firm GPW was understood to be starting due diligence work on SSL International, for a corporate client. An spokesman for SSL, which makes the famous Durex brand of condom, would not to comment on "market speculation". However the news sent shares in SSL, which also makes Scholl footwear, up more than 6%, or 16.75 pence to 293.5p.
 
 The FT said most the high-profile firm that might woo SSL was Anglo-Dutch household products group Reckitt Benckiser. Eighteen months ago Reckitt Benckiser was at the centre of a rumoured takeover bid for SSL - but that came to nothing. Other firms that have been seen as would-be suitors include Kimberly-Clark, Johnson & Johnson, and private equity investors. Analysts have seen SSL as a takeover target for years. It sold off its surgical gloves and antiseptics businesses for £173m to a management team in May. SSL was formed by a three-way merger between Seton Healthcare, footwear specialists Scholl and condom-maker London International Group. Its other brands include Syndol analgesic, Meltus cough medicine, Sauber compression hosiery and deodorant products, and Mister Baby.
llama3.2:1b: UK condom maker Durex maker SSL International has refused to comment on takeover speculation, but shares in the company increased by 16.75% after a Financial Times report mentioned GPW as starting due diligence work on it. The firm has sold off its surgical gloves and antiseptics businesses for £173m to management in May, making it a potential target for other companies.
llama3.2:3b: UK condom maker SSL International faces potential takeover bid from Reckitt Benckiser, with GPW starting due diligence work for an undisclosed client. Shares rose 6% as news sent shockwaves through the company. Analysts have seen SSL as a target for years, following its previous sale of surgical gloves and antiseptics businesses for £173m.
gemma2:2b:
SSL International, maker of Durex condoms, is the subject of potential takeover bids from companies like Reckitt Benckiser. The company has refused to comment on market speculation surrounding a possible acquisition.  
Shares in SSL rose significantly following the news of potential interest. 
The company owns various other brands in addition to Durex and Scholl footwear.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK-based condom maker SSL International is reportedly being pursued by a major company for the acquisition of its Durex brand (SSL brand) in 2005. The Financial Times reported that business intelligence firm GPW was reviewing SSL's corporate client due diligence work before making any decisions. SSL, which makes various brands like London International Group and London Medical Products, is currently up more than 6% or $16.75 per share on the FT after receiving positive news from the FT about Reckitt Benckiser buying SSL. Analysts have suggested that SSL could be a potential target for a major acquisition in the not-so-distant future.
qwen2.5:1.5b: UK condom maker SSL International has refused to comment on reports it may be subject to a takeover in early 2005, citing "market speculation". Shares of the company rose more than 6% following rumors of a potential deal with business intelligence firm GPW. The FT mentions that Reckitt Benckiser and other firms have expressed interest in SSL over the years but no action has been taken so far.
qwen2.5:3b: UK condom maker SSL International has refused to comment on reports of a potential takeover early in 2005 by business intelligence firm GPW for a corporate client. An FT report suggests Reckitt Benckiser might be the main contender among Anglo-Dutch household products group, Kimberly-Clark, Johnson & Johnson, and private equity investors who have shown interest in SSL International over years. The company's shares spiked after the news due to its sale of surgical gloves and antiseptics businesses for £173m last year, which left it with brands like Durex condoms, Scholl footwear, Syndol analgesic, Meltus cough medicine, Sauber compression hosiery, deodorant products, and Mister Baby.

Reckitt Benckiser was rumored for a potential bid for SSL in 2014, but it failed to materialize.
